skill.name: vibe-security
skill.description: Security intelligence for code analysis. Detects SQL injection, XSS, CSRF, authentication issues, crypto failures, and more. Actions: scan, analyze, fix, audit, check, review, secure, validate, sanitize, protect. Languages: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, PHP, Java, Go, Ruby. Frameworks: Express, Django, Flask, Laravel, Spring, Rails. Vulnerabilities: SQL injection, XSS, CSRF, authentication bypass, authorization issues, command injection, path traversal, insecure deserialization, weak crypto, sensitive data exposure. Topics: input validation, output encoding, parameterized queries, password hashing, session management, CORS, CSP, security headers, rate limiting, dependency scanning.

security_audit.summary: Legitimate security scanning tool with no malicious patterns. Contains Python scripts and filesystem access required for code analysis. Uses subprocess only for standard package manager audit tools (npm, pip-audit, cargo). All data processing is local with no exfiltration.

low_findings.title: External subprocess execution for package scanning
low_findings.description: The CVE integration module uses subprocess to invoke package manager audit tools: npm audit (lines 33-39), pip-audit (lines 72-77), and cargo audit (lines 148-154). These are legitimate security scanning operations but represent external command execution that requires trust.

content.value_statement: Code security vulnerabilities can lead to data breaches and system compromise. This skill identifies SQL injection, XSS, command injection, and other vulnerabilities through AST-based analysis and pattern matching. It provides actionable fixes with confidence scores.
actual_capabilities: AST-based semantic analysis for Python code
Data flow tracking to detect tainted data propagation
Pattern matching for JavaScript and TypeScript vulnerabilities
Dependency vulnerability scanning via npm, pip, and cargo audit
Automated fix suggestions with test generation
Security reports in HTML, JSON, CSV, and SARIF formats
limitations: No runtime protection or live vulnerability blocking
Limited to supported languages (JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, PHP)
Fix suggestions may require manual review for complex code
Does not scan compiled binaries or encrypted code

output_examples.input: Scan src/database.js for SQL injection vulnerabilities
output: Code: db.query(`SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ${userId}`)

best_practices: Run security scans before every code commit or pull request
Address critical and high severity vulnerabilities immediately
Review fix suggestions before applying to production code
Use parameterized queries instead of string concatenation for all database operations
anti_patterns: Using string concatenation to build SQL queries
Passing user input directly to eval() or exec() functions
Assigning unsanitized user input to innerHTML properties
Using weak cryptographic algorithms like MD5 or SHA1

faq.question: Which programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, PHP, Java, Go, and Ruby are supported for vulnerability scanning.

faq.question: What is the maximum file size for scanning?
faq.answer: Files are processed in memory. Very large files may take longer but there is no hard size limit.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes. Reports can be generated in JSON and SARIF formats for GitHub Code Scanning and other CI systems.

faq.question: Is my code sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. All analysis runs locally on your machine. Dependencies are checked against public databases locally.

faq.question: What should I do if scans timeout?
faq.answer: Try scanning smaller files or directories. Increase subprocess timeout values in the script if needed.

faq.question: How does this compare to Snyk or npm audit?
faq.answer: This tool provides code-level vulnerability detection. Use it alongside dependency scanners like Snyk for comprehensive coverage.
